creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
There are quite a few files in SVN with what appear to be incorrect SVN properties, e.g. eol-style is incorrect, or file is executable when it should not be.

Script files to follow can be used on Unix or Windows, but should be used on whatever OS was used to update the files last so that the EOLs are correct.

markt@apache.org
text: .bat and .sh should use svn:eol-style:native. Using platform specific settings makes editing these files on anther platform a right pain.

(In reply to comment #4)
> .bat and .sh should use svn:eol-style:native. Using platform specific settings
> makes editing these files on anther platform a right pain.
> 

That depends on what tool you use to do the edits.

Eclipse (for example) will happily edit eol=LF on Windows.

If the "wrong" line endings are used, then the scripts have to fixed in order to generate releases.
creator: sebb@apache.org
markt@apache.org
text:
There are also plenty of tools that don't like non-native line-endings .

The build scripts take care of this for the releases.
